Jacques Offenbach - Belle Helene
Jacques Offenbach - La belle Helene
Year : 1996 Label : ZDF, RM Arts, Arthaus Musik Country of origin : Switzerland Genre : Operetta Duration : 2:03:38 Language : French Translation : Not required Subtitles : Russian Choir and Orchestra : Zurich Opera Conductor : Nikolaus Harnoncourt (Nikolaus Harnoncourt) Director / Choreographer : Helmut Lohner (Helmut Lohner), Hartmut Shottler (Hartmut Schottler) Artists : Veselin Katsarova (Vesselina Kasarova) - Helen, Queen of Sparta Deon von der Waltham (Deon van der Walt) - Paris, son of King Priam Carlos Chausson (Carlos Chausson) - Calchas, the high priest of Jupiter Volker Vogel (Volker Vogel) - Menelaus, King of Sparta , Oliver Widmer (Oliver Widmer) - Agamemnon, King of Argos Liliana Nikityanu (Liliana Nikiteanu) - Orest , the son of Agamemnon Ruben Amoretti (Ruben Amoretti) - Ajax Great, king of Salamis Cheney Davidson (Cheyne Davidson) - Small Ajax (Ajax "fleet-footed"), King Lakridy Devislim Steve (Steve Davislim) - Achilles, King Fthiotida Ruth Rohner (Ruth Rohner) - Bacchides, the servant of Helen Ulrika Precht (Ulrika Precht) - Lyon courtesan Lisa Larsson (Lisa Larsson) - Partenida, courtesan Carl Colby (Karl Adam) - Filokom, Calchas servant Jean-Paul Beglin (Jean-Paul Beglin) - Evtiky Jakob Baumann (Jakob Baumann) - Slave Description : A masterpiece of satire and entertainment genre. Established in 1864, the operetta "The Beautiful Helen" in an ironic tone and juicy details tells the story of the fatal love prince of Paris to the daughter of Zeus and Leda - beauty Elena, the wife of King Menelaus. As you know, stealing Helen, Paris started the Trojan War. But the saga of the Great War are least interested in Offenbach and librettists, in a play which the gods and kings have become parodies of images: fools, slackers, sensualist and gluttons, and only the love theme has been widely developed in the beautiful arias, duets, ensembles, requiring virtuoso performers of ownership vocal skills. Thanks to the production of "Beautiful Helena" genre of operetta established on the Russian stage. She gained such wide popularity that her music could be heard even in music boxes. So, Chekhov in August 1883 Leikin wrote: "... Someone has got the box, and I hear," Helen of Troy "...". Perhaps for the first time this operetta Chekhov heard in his youth, as it was part of the repertoire of the Taganrog Theatre, haunted future writer. During the performance, the audience roar with laughter, haunting light graceful melodies, and then joined in singing favorite arias.
